parts:
I can't directly display or analyze the contents of the electric bill due to the tool's limitations. However, I can provide general advice on reducing peak demand charges:

1. **Monitor Peak Hours**: Understand when peak hours occur and reduce consumption during these times.
2. **Shift Usage**: If possible, operate heavy machinery or do energy-intensive tasks during off-peak hours.
3. **Energy Efficiency**: Invest in energy-efficient appliances and lighting.
4. **Maintenance**: Regularly maintain equipment to ensure it's operating efficiently.
5. **Energy Management System**: Consider installing a system to monitor and control energy use more effectively.

For a precise analysis, consider consulting with an energy management specialist or performing a detailed audit of your energy usage patterns.

content.result:
# 【0†PECO†www.peco.com】
PECO offers a Time-Of-Use Pricing program that allows customers to pay different rates for electricity based on the time of day and season. This webpage answers some frequently asked questions about how the program works, who can participate, and what are the benefits and risks of choosing this option. Find out if Time-Of-Use Pricing is right for you and how to enroll.
# 【1†Inside the surprising lessons from PECO's time-of-use rate pilot ...†www.utilitydive.com】
“PECO Smart Time Pricing has a peak generation rate of $0.1595 per kWh on weekdays from 2 to 6 pm, excluding holidays, and an off-peak generation rate of $0.0685 per kWh during the remaining...
# 【2†Pa. commission approves PECO Energy time-of-use rate plan†www.spglobal.com】
Under the approved rate design, "peak" rates will be in effect from 2 p.m. to 6 p.m. Monday through Friday, with "super off-peak" rates lasting from midnight until 6 a.m. every day. All other hours will have "off-peak" rates.
# 【3†Peco plans hourly rates to encourage customers to shift energy use to ...†www.inquirer.com】
The Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission approved a formal plan allowing Peco to roll out “time-of-use” rates for customers, with the idea that discount rates for electricity consumed at night would encourage them to shift usage to off-peak hours. The plan would be voluntary, and customers could opt to stick with Peco’s current flat-rate pricing.
# 【4†Time of Use Energy in Pennsylvania - papowerswitch.com†www.papowerswitch.com】
1. Use electric appliances, like dishwashers and ovens, during off-peak hours. 2. Set timers on your thermostat, water heaters and pool pumps to go on during off-peak hours. 3. Charge your electric vehicle during off-peak hours. Common Time of Use Program Details Each energy supplier handles time of use programs differently.
# 【5†Peak Savers Pilot Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)†www.pepco.com】
2. What are peak hours? What are the rates and times for peak and off-peak hours? Peak hours are times when homes and businesses use the most electricity. Peak hours change seasonally because of differences in the peak usage due to heating and cooling. Currently, customers pay a flat rate for energy no matter when they use it.
# 【6†PA Time-Of-Use Pricing - FirstEnergy Corp.†www.firstenergycorp.com】
Help PA Time-Of-Use Pricing You may be able to save by shifting your energy usage. Time-of-Use (TOU) Pricing is offered as an optional, generation-only rate for smart-metered, non-Customer Assistance Program (CAP) residential and small commercial customers.
# 【7†View Account Usage Data | PECO - An Exelon Company†azstg-secure.peco.com】
Welcome to PECO Presentment Customer Usage. Please enter your Account Number (please omit the dash but include any leading zeros), and Zip Code associated with this account in the space provided below. This web site is for the sole use of PECO Energy Company ("PECO"), its parent company Exelon Corporation, and PECO's customers and the customers ...
# 【8†Peak Savers Calculator | Pepco - An Exelon Company†www.pepco.com】
The more energy you shift or reduce to off-peak hours, the more you can save. Example: If you are estimating your usage, multiply the hourly kWh times the number of hours you use that appliance. June - September (Summer Season) Between 2pm - 7pm kWh. Peak (total for 5 hours) Outside 2pm - 7pm kWh. Off-Peak (total for 19 hours) October - May ...
# 【9†PECO Procurement For Default Supply†www.pecoprocurement.com】
The Total Peak (MW) and Default Peak (MW) for each Class provided in the Addendum to the RFP Rules was updated on December 19, 2023 for Planning Year 2024-2025. Historical daily peak load contribution data for the total retail load, default service customers and for customers served by EGSs is available by Class and strata in the Data Room.
# 【10†OATT, ATTACHMENT M-2 (PECO Energy Company)†agreements.pjm.com】
PECO calculates a weather-normalized peak load for each of these five hours, taking into account the actual reading, actual versus normal peak weather, customer rate class, and losses. 3. To calculate the preliminary PLC, PECO averages the five resulting load values. B. FOR WHOLESALE MONTHLY-SETLLED LOCATIONS WITH DEMAND METERS: 1.
# 【11†Time-of-Use Rate - PEC - Pedernales Electric Cooperative, Inc.†www.pec.coop】
Our Time-of-Use Rate can help you save money if you’re able to reduce your energy use during peak times (when electricity prices are highest) or shift energy use to off-peak periods (when electricity prices are lowest). Rate periods & seasons Pricing for electricity under our Time-of-Use Rate option is different depending on the time of day.
# 【12†Pennsylvania PECO Utility - Switch to TOU Rate Plan? - Tesla Motors Club†teslamotorsclub.com】
Average house base load is 1.1-1.3kW 24/7/365. Current flat PECO rate $0.145kWh w/full net metering. No EV (maybe a PHEV within a year) Heat and HW is propane. Everything else is electric (drier, cooking, pool heat pump) TOU Rate Plan. Peak Weekdays: (2 p.m. – 6 p.m.) - $0.283kWh.

parts: PECO determines peak usage hours as part of their Time-of-Use Pricing program. Generally, "peak" rates are in effect during hours when energy demand is highest, typically on weekdays. Specifically, for PECO, peak rates apply from 2 p.m. to 6 p.m. Monday through Friday, excluding holidays. This is the period when electricity is typically most expensive due to higher demand. To take advantage of lower rates, it's beneficial to shift your energy usage to off-peak hours, which for PECO include all other hours outside of the 2 p.m. to 6 p.m. window on weekdays, with "super off-peak" rates applying from midnight until 6 a.m. every day【8†source】【8†source】.
For more information, check out these [search results](https://chat.openai.com/backend-api/bing/redirect?query=PECO%20peak%20usage%20hours%20determination).
how does rooftop solar lower peak demand?  Is there a standard multiplier that is used?

Rooftop solar can significantly lower peak demand charges in the following ways:

1. **Direct Reduction in Demand**: Solar panels generate electricity during the day, often aligning with peak demand hours (especially in the afternoon when the sun is at its highest). This can directly reduce the amount of electricity you need to draw from the grid during these expensive times.

2. **Net Metering**: Some utilities offer net metering, where excess electricity generated by your solar panels is sent back to the grid, effectively reducing your net energy consumption. This can also offset demand during peak hours if your system produces more power than you use at that time.

3. **Use of Solar Batteries**: If paired with a storage system (solar batteries), solar panels can provide even more benefits. You can store the energy produced during the day (when demand and production are high) and use it during peak hours or at night, further reducing your demand from the grid.

Regarding a standard multiplier, there isn't a universally applicable one because the impact of rooftop solar on peak demand charges depends on several factors:

- **Size and orientation of the solar system**: Larger systems that are well-oriented (e.g., facing south in the Northern Hemisphere) will produce more electricity.
- **Geographical location**: Areas with more sunlight will naturally yield more solar power.
- **Time-of-Use rates**: The structure of electricity rates and how they coincide with solar production times can affect savings.
- **Local policies**: Incentives, net metering policies, and other local regulations can impact the financial return of installing solar panels.

To get a precise calculation of how rooftop solar would affect your peak demand charges, it would be best to consult with a solar provider or an energy specialist who can analyze your specific situation, including your energy usage pattern, the local rate structure, and the potential solar system's size and orientation. They can provide a more tailored analysis and possibly even a simulation of your expected savings.
Can PECO provide 15 minute inverval usage information?

Yes, PECO can provide 15-minute interval usage information to customers. This level of detailed data is typically available through advanced metering infrastructure (AMI), commonly known as smart meters. Smart meters record electricity consumption in short intervals, such as every 15 minutes, and transmit this data back to the utility.

Customers with smart meters installed can often access their interval data through:

1. **Online Customer Portals**: Utilities like PECO usually offer online portals where customers can log in to view their usage data, track their energy consumption patterns, and sometimes get recommendations for energy savings.

2. **Energy Management Systems**: Businesses and individuals with more complex energy management needs might use specialized software or services that can take this 15-minute interval data and provide more comprehensive analytics or automation to optimize energy usage.

3. **Direct Requests**: If the information isn't readily available through an online portal, customers can contact the utility directly to request their usage data.

This granular data is particularly useful for identifying peak usage times and evaluating the effectiveness of measures taken to reduce peak demand charges. If you're a PECO customer interested in this data, it's advisable to check their specific offerings or contact them directly for how you can access your 15-minute interval usage information.

parts: The bill indicates a peak demand (Pk kW) of 427.20 kW with a total consumption of 173,098 kWh for the service period from 09/01/2023 to 10/03/2023. The peak demand charge is a significant part of the bill, calculated by multiplying the peak kW by the rate (427 kW X $5.49000). To reduce these charges, consider implementing energy-saving measures during peak hours, using energy-efficient appliances, and possibly investing in energy management systems or solar solutions to offset peak demand.
how will rooftop solar effect the peak demand charges.  Please be specific and create data for a site in Horsham, PA

In Horsham, PA, rooftop solar can significantly affect peak demand charges by generating electricity during the high-demand (and high-cost) afternoon hours. With Horsham's decent sunlight exposure, a properly sized and oriented system might reduce peak demand by a substantial percentage. For example, a system producing 300 kW during peak hours could reduce the peak demand from 427.20 kW to 127.20 kW, significantly lowering the demand charges, considering PECO's rate of $5.49000 per kW for peak demand. Actual savings depend on specific conditions like system size, orientation, and weather patterns.
recalculate the entire bill assuming a rooftop solar array

To recalculate the entire bill assuming a rooftop solar array that reduces the peak demand from 427.20 kW to 127.20 kW, we'll make a few assumptions:

1. **Peak Demand Charges**:
   - Original: 427.20 kW * $5.49000/kW = $2,345.08
   - With Solar: 127.20 kW * $5.49000/kW = $698.52
   - Reduction: $2,345.08 - $698.52 = $1,646.56

2. **Energy Charges**:
   - Assuming the solar array generates enough to cover a portion of the consumption, let's say it covers 30% of the 173,098 kWh.
   - Solar Production: 173,098 kWh * 30% = 51,929.4 kWh
   - Remaining Consumption: 173,098 kWh - 51,929.4 kWh = 121,168.6 kWh
   - If the energy rate is $0.10/kWh (hypothetical rate for calculation):
      - Original: 173,098 kWh * $0.10/kWh = $17,309.80
      - With Solar: 121,168.6 kWh * $0.10/kWh = $12,116.86
      - Reduction: $17,309.80 - $12,116.86 = $5,192.94

3. **Total Bill**:
   - Original Total: $2,345.08 (Peak) + $17,309.80 (Energy) = $19,654.88
   - With Solar Total: $698.52 (Peak) + $12,116.86 (Energy) = $12,815.38
   - Total Reduction: $19,654.88 - $12,815.38 = $6,839.50

These calculations are approximations and the actual figures will depend on specific rates, the performance of the solar system, and the consumption pattern of the facility. It's also worth noting that there might be other charges or credits on the bill that could be affected by installing a solar system, such as distribution charges or solar incentives. For a precise calculation, it's recommended to consult with a solar provider or energy consultant.
assume solar offsets all monthly usage and is net metered

Assuming the solar offsets all monthly usage and is net metered, your energy charges would effectively be zero as the solar production would cover all consumption. The peak demand charge would still apply, but only for the demand not met by solar during peak times. If the solar array completely covers peak demand:

1. **Peak Demand Charges**: Reduced to zero if solar covers the entire 427.20 kW during peak times.
2. **Energy Charges**: Zero, since all usage is offset by solar production.
3. **Total Bill**: Essentially reduced to any fixed charges, taxes, or fees that are part of the bill aside from energy and demand charges.

A solar installation of this capacity would significantly reduce the energy bill, primarily leaving only the unavoidable fixed charges.
in your 30% example assume energy rate is $.063

Let's recalculate the energy charges with the new rate of $0.063 per kWh, assuming the solar array offsets 30% of the consumption:

1. **Energy Charges**:
   - Solar Production: 173,098 kWh * 30% = 51,929.4 kWh
   - Remaining Consumption: 173,098 kWh - 51,929.4 kWh = 121,168.6 kWh
   - New Energy Rate: $0.063/kWh
   - Energy Charges with Solar: 121,168.6 kWh * $0.063/kWh = $7,633.62

2. **Total Bill with Solar**:
   - Assuming the peak demand charge is the same as in the previous example ($698.52):
   - Total with Solar: $698.52 (Peak) + $7,633.62 (Energy) = $8,332.14
   - This reflects the new total bill with the adjusted energy rate and the impact of the solar production.
assume peak period is 2 to 6pm.  Does this change solar's effect on peak charges?

Yes, the peak period being from 2 to 6 pm does influence solar's effect on peak charges. Solar panels produce the most electricity when the sun is at its highest, which typically coincides with this period. If your solar production peaks during these hours, it's more likely to offset your peak demand, reducing the demand charges even further. This alignment means solar can be very effective in reducing peak charges, especially on sunny days.
Please create a table comparing the current bill with the 30% hypothetical example

| Charge Type       | Current Bill | With 30% Solar Offset & Rate at $0.063 |
|-------------------|--------------|----------------------------------------|
| Peak Demand (kW)  | 427.20 kW    | 127.20 kW (assuming solar covers peak) |
| Peak Charge Rate  | $5.49000/kW  | $5.49000/kW                            |
| Peak Demand Cost  | $2,345.08    | $698.52                                |
| Energy Usage (kWh)| 173,098 kWh  | 121,168.6 kWh (70% of original usage)  |
| Energy Rate       | Not provided | $0.063/kWh                             |
| Energy Cost       | Not provided | $7,633.62                              |
| Total Bill        | Not provided | $8,332.14 (Peak + Energy)              |

This table compares the current bill with a hypothetical scenario where a solar array offsets 30% of the energy usage and reduces the peak demand significantly. The total bill with solar is based on the new peak demand cost and the energy cost calculated with the reduced consumption at the rate of $0.063/kWh.
please assume same energy cost for curent and for solar

Here's a revised table assuming the same energy cost rate for both the current bill and the hypothetical solar scenario:

| Charge Type       | Current Bill ($0.063/kWh) | With 30% Solar Offset ($0.063/kWh) |
|-------------------|---------------------------|------------------------------------|
| Peak Demand (kW)  | 427.20 kW                 | 127.20 kW                          |
| Peak Charge Rate  | $5.49000/kW               | $5.49000/kW                        |
| Peak Demand Cost  | $2,345.08                 | $698.52                            |
| Energy Usage (kWh)| 173,098 kWh               | 121,168.6 kWh (70% of original)    |
| Energy Rate       | $0.063/kWh                | $0.063/kWh                         |
| Energy Cost       | $10,905.18                | $7,633.62                          |
| Total Bill        | $13,250.26                | $8,332.14 (Peak + Energy)          |

This table illustrates the impact of a 30% solar offset on both peak demand and energy costs, showing a substantial reduction in the total bill.
please assume peak hours of 2 to 6pm

Assuming peak hours are from 2 to 6 pm, and if the solar production aligns well with this period, it can significantly reduce the peak demand charges. However, the total energy offset by the solar system remains the same (30%). Here's the revised bill estimate:

| Charge Type       | Current Bill ($0.063/kWh) | With 30% Solar Offset ($0.063/kWh) |
|-------------------|---------------------------|------------------------------------|
| Peak Demand (kW)  | 427.20 kW                 | Likely reduced significantly due to alignment with solar production hours |
| Peak Charge Rate  | $5.49000/kW               | $5.49000/kW                        |
| Peak Demand Cost  | $2,345.08                 | Reduced, exact value depends on actual solar production during peak hours |
| Energy Usage (kWh)| 173,098 kWh               | 121,168.6 kWh (70% of original)    |
| Energy Rate       | $0.063/kWh                | $0.063/kWh                         |
| Energy Cost       | $10,905.18                | $7,633.62                          |
| Total Bill        | $13,250.26                | Lower, specific value depends on peak demand reduction |

The exact reduction in peak demand charges would depend on the actual performance of the solar system during the peak hours of 2 to 6 pm. The energy cost savings remain as calculated with a 30% offset by solar.
assume solar efficiency factor of 1.25 and assume this bill is for September

With a solar efficiency factor of 1.25 and considering September's solar generation potential, the solar system might produce more energy during peak hours, further reducing the peak demand charges. This efficiency factor means the system operates at 125% of its nominal capacity during optimal conditions, which are likely in September due to longer daylight hours and generally clear skies. This would further decrease the peak kW during 2 to 6 pm, leading to a lower total bill, especially in the peak demand cost section. Exact savings would depend on actual solar production and consumption patterns.
please demonstrate in table
please demonstrate in table and please quantify demand savings to the best of your ability

Given the solar efficiency factor of 1.25 and the bill being for September, here's how the bill might look:

| Charge Type       | Current Bill ($0.063/kWh) | With 30% Solar Offset & Efficiency 1.25 ($0.063/kWh) |
|-------------------|---------------------------|------------------------------------------------------|
| Peak Demand (kW)  | 427.20 kW                 | Reduced further due to increased solar efficiency    |
| Peak Charge Rate  | $5.49000/kW               | $5.49000/kW                                          |
| Peak Demand Cost  | $2,345.08                 | Further reduced from $698.52                          |
| Energy Usage (kWh)| 173,098 kWh               | 121,168.6 kWh (70% of original)                      |
| Energy Rate       | $0.063/kWh                | $0.063/kWh                                           |
| Energy Cost       | $10,905.18                | $7,633.62                                            |
| Total Bill        | $13,250.26                | Lower due to efficiency and peak alignment           |

The efficiency factor and solar generation during peak hours in September would likely reduce the peak demand costs more than the initial calculation, but the exact figures depend on the system's actual output and consumption patterns.
assume normal solar production aligned with National Weather Service historical data for Philadelphia, PA

For Philadelphia, PA, assuming normal solar production aligned with the National Weather Service's historical data, we'd expect the solar panels to be quite effective in September. This period typically has a good number of sunny days, allowing the solar system to perform near its optimal capacity, especially during the peak hours of 2 to 6 pm. This would result in a noticeable reduction in both the peak demand charges and the overall energy consumption on the bill.
can you extrapolate the table to an annual analysis?

content.text:
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Data extracted from the image provided for each month
data = {
    'Month': ['January', 'February', 'March', 'April', 'May', 'June', 'July', 'August', 
              'September', 'October', 'November', 'December'],
    'kWh': [72107, 68495, 60161, 51867, 58679, 54664, 59227, 54910, 54747, 59207, 71242, 89570],
    'Total': [18279.00, 10775.99, 7398.71, 6301.00, 8765.00, 9056.30, 14884.25, 9363.00, 10880.89, 12791.00, 17302.91, 22620.00],
    'Demand': [605.64, 510.88, 520.70, 393.60, 429.50, 434.01, 2760.46, 414.46, 405.49, 510.88, 552.08, 568.56],
    'Delivery Service Demand': [691.50, 585.47, 553.72, 422.92, 479.60, 488.32, 3078.16, 488.32, 453.44, 571.16, 588.60, 222.36],
    'Customer Charge': [97.00] * 12,
    'MD USC': [36.85] * 12,
    'TOTAL': [16848.01, 9545.79, 6190.44, 5350.63, 7722.05, 8000.12, 8911.78, 8326.37, 9888.11, 11575.11, 16028.38, 21695.23],
    'Solar Production': [32600, 40800, 63200, 78600, 87100, 95100, 90400, 80100, 64400, 55100, 33500, 29000]
}

# Create a DataFrame
df = pd.DataFrame(data)

# Define the rate of electricity
rate = 0.063

# Calculate new total assuming solar offsets 100% of the kWh usage
# We assume the demand charges are eliminated by the solar production during peak hours
df['New Total'] = df['Customer Charge'] + df['MD USC']

# Assuming the solar production is enough to cover the entire demand during the 2 to 6 pm peak,
# we reduce the Demand and Delivery Service Demand to zero for September as an example
df.loc[df['Month'] == 'September', 'Demand'] = 0
df.loc[df['Month'] == 'September', 'Delivery Service Demand'] = 0

# Calculate savings
df['Savings'] = df['TOTAL'] - df['New Total']

# Output the modified DataFrame
df[['Month', 'kWh', 'TOTAL', 'Solar Production', 'New Total', 'Savings']]

parts:
An annual analysis would require considering seasonal variations in both energy consumption and solar production. Factors like shorter days in winter, potential snow cover on panels, and higher energy usage for heating would be balanced against longer summer days and potentially higher cooling costs. The table below provides a rough annual extrapolation, assuming the September solar efficiency and production levels are representative of an average month and adjusting for less effective winter months:

| Charge Type       | Current Annual Cost ($0.063/kWh) | With Solar & Efficiency 1.25 ($0.063/kWh) |
|-------------------|----------------------------------|-------------------------------------------|
| Peak Demand Cost  | $28,140.96 (12 x $2,345.08)      | Significantly Reduced                     |
| Energy Cost       | $130,862.16 (12 x $10,905.18)    | $91,603.44 (12 x $7,633.62)               |
| Total Annual Cost | $159,003.12                      | Significantly Lower                       |

This table assumes solar production remains consistently beneficial throughout the year, which may not be the case. Actual annual savings could vary, especially due to seasonal changes affecting solar efficiency and energy consumption patterns. For precise figures, a detailed month-by-month analysis considering these factors is recommended.

please analyze this spreadsheet and calculate how much the solar production will offset the peak demand charges.  Assume utility is BGE and location is in Hanover, MD.  Please assume BGE peak hours for multifamily rates

please analyze this spreadsheet and calculate how much the solar production will offset the peak demand charges.  Assume utility is BGE and location is in Hanover, MD.  Please assume BGE peak hours for multifamily rates

I am currently experiencing technical issues that prevent me from creating the table with the specifics you requested. However, I can guide you through the process of how to calculate it manually:

1. **Demand Savings**:
   - To calculate the demand savings, you need to know the demand reduction during peak hours (2 to 6 pm) attributable to solar production. Since solar panels produce more during these hours, if we assume solar production covers the peak demand completely, the savings would be the entire demand charge. For September, this is reflected in the 'Demand' and 'Delivery Service Demand' columns.
   
2. **Energy Charge Reduction**:
   - With the solar efficiency factor of 1.25, the solar panels will produce more energy than their rated output during peak sunlight hours. You will calculate the total solar production in kWh for September, apply the efficiency factor, and subtract this from the total kWh to determine the net energy use.

3. **Total Bill Calculation**:
   - Once you have the net energy use, multiply this by the energy rate ($0.063/kWh) to find the new energy charge. Add any fixed charges such as 'Customer Charge' and 'MD USC' to this to get the new total bill.

4. **Comparison**:
   - To demonstrate the savings, you can subtract the new total bill from the original total bill for September.

Once the technical issue is resolved, I can assist you in generating a precise table with these calculations.

To calculate how much solar production will offset peak demand charges, we need to know the specific peak hours for multifamily rates set by BGE (Baltimore Gas and Electric). Typically, these peak hours are during the afternoon when solar production is also at its peak. However, without the specific peak hours from BGE, I will assume a common peak period of 2 pm to 6 pm for the purpose of this analysis.

Here’s how the calculation would work:

1. **Determine the Peak Demand Reduction**: If solar production occurs during the BGE peak hours, we need to calculate the amount of power produced by the solar panels during these hours and subtract it from the original peak demand.

2. **Calculate the New Peak Demand Charges**: Using the reduced peak demand figure, we multiply it by the peak demand rate to get the new peak demand charges.

3. **Account for Solar Production**: We must ensure that the solar production is within the peak demand timeframe to offset the demand charges correctly.

Given the data provided, we can't directly calculate the savings without the specific peak demand rate and without knowing how the 15-minute interval demand (kW) coincides with the solar production intervals. However, for the sake of this example, we will assume that all solar production occurs during the peak period and offsets the demand proportionally.

Let's proceed with the calculation under these assumptions.

content.text:
# BGE peak hours for multifamily rates are assumed to be from 2 pm to 6 pm. 
# Assuming the solar production aligns with this period, we can estimate the peak demand offset.

# We will use the solar production to reduce the demand proportionally for the September month.
# We will calculate the peak demand cost assuming that the solar production covers the peak demand fully during these hours.

# We need the peak demand rate for the calculation. We will use a placeholder value since the actual rate is not provided.
# Please replace the 'peak_demand_rate' with the actual rate from BGE for an accurate calculation.

peak_demand_rate = 5.49000  # Hypothetical rate in $/kW
solar_efficiency_factor = 1.25  # Solar is 25% more productive during peak hours

# We will assume that the peak demand occurs for 4 hours each day for the entire month.
# We will assume 30 days for September for simplicity.

# Calculate the potential peak demand reduction in kW for September assuming full coverage of demand by solar.
peak_hours_per_day = 4
days_in_september = 30
solar_production_september = df.loc[df['Month'] == 'September', 'Solar Production'].values[0]
peak_demand_reduction_kW = solar_production_september * solar_efficiency_factor / (peak_hours_per_day * days_in_september)

# Calculate the peak demand cost for September after solar production offset
new_peak_demand_cost_september = max(df.loc[df['Month'] == 'September', 'Demand'].values[0] - peak_demand_reduction_kW, 0) * peak_demand_rate
df.loc[df['Month'] == 'September', 'New Demand Cost'] = new_peak_demand_cost_september

# Calculate the savings in peak demand cost for September due to solar production
df.loc[df['Month'] == 'September', 'Demand Savings'] = df.loc[df['Month'] == 'September', 'Demand'].values[0] * peak_demand_rate - new_peak_demand_cost_september

# Display the updated DataFrame with the new peak demand cost and savings for September
df[['Month', 'Demand', 'Solar Production', 'New Demand Cost', 'Demand Savings']]

To calculate how much solar production will offset the peak demand charges for a location in Hanover, MD, with BGE (Baltimore Gas and Electric) as the utility, we need to consider BGE's peak hours for multifamily rates. Unfortunately, the specific peak hours for multifamily rates are not provided in the spreadsheet. To accurately assess the offset, we would need to know the peak hours applicable to the multifamily rates.

However, I can provide a general approach for calculating the potential offset:

1. **Determine BGE's Multifamily Peak Hours**: You'll need to obtain the exact peak hours for multifamily rates from BGE. These hours can vary, and BGE should provide this information.

2. **Match Solar Production to Peak Hours**: Once you have the peak hours, you can match the solar production data to those hours for each month. Calculate the total solar production during those peak hours.

3. **Calculate Peak Demand Reduction**: Subtract the solar production during peak hours from the corresponding demand charges for each month. This will give you the reduction in peak demand charges due to solar production.

4. **Sum Up the Reductions**: Finally, sum up the reductions for all months to find the total reduction in peak demand charges over the year.

Please provide the specific peak hours for multifamily rates from BGE, and I can assist further with the calculations.
assume peak hours of 2-6 pm

Great, with the assumption of peak hours from 2 to 6 pm, we can calculate how much the solar production will offset the peak demand charges for each month. Here's the analysis:

1. **Calculate Solar Production During Peak Hours**: We'll calculate the solar production during the 2-6 pm peak hours for each month based on the provided solar production data.

2. **Calculate Peak Demand Reduction**: The solar production during peak hours will reduce the peak demand charges for each month. We'll calculate this reduction by multiplying the solar production during peak hours by the rate applicable to peak demand charges.

3. **Sum Up the Reductions**: Finally, we'll sum up the reductions for all months to find the total reduction in peak demand charges over the year.

Let's proceed with the calculations:

content.text:
# Let's define the necessary parameters for the calculation.
peak_demand_rate = 5.49000 # Hypothetical peak demand rate in $/kW

# Calculating the potential reduction in peak demand cost for September.
# We're assuming that the entire solar production is effective in reducing the peak demand.
# The solar efficiency factor of 1.25 suggests that the solar panels produce 25% more during peak hours.
# However, without the exact peak hours from BGE, this is a simplification.

# Extract the peak demand and solar production for September
september_peak_demand = data['Demand'][8] # Demand in kW
september_solar_production = data['Solar Production'][8] # Solar Production in kWh

# Assuming the peak hours are 4 hours per day, we'll calculate the daily solar production during peak hours.
# Considering there are typically 30 days in September:
days_in_september = 30
peak_hours_per_day = 4 # 2 pm to 6 pm
solar_production_during_peak = (september_solar_production / (30 * 24)) * peak_hours_per_day * days_in_september

# The peak demand reduction is the solar production during peak hours, adjusted by the solar efficiency factor.
peak_demand_reduction = solar_production_during_peak * solar_efficiency_factor

# If the solar production during peak hours is more than the peak demand, it's fully offset.
# Otherwise, it's reduced by the amount of solar production.
if peak_demand_reduction >= september_peak_demand:
    new_peak_demand = 0
else:
    new_peak_demand = september_peak_demand - peak_demand_reduction

# Recalculate the demand charges with the potential new peak demand.
new_demand_charge = new_peak_demand * peak_demand_rate

# Savings is the difference between the original demand charges and the new demand charges.
demand_savings = september_peak_demand * peak_demand_rate - new_demand_charge

# Now we create a DataFrame to display the results
comparison_data = {
    'Description': ['Original Peak Demand', 'Solar Production', 'Solar Efficiency Factor', 
                    'New Peak Demand', 'Original Demand Charges', 'New Demand Charges', 'Demand Savings'],
    'September': [september_peak_demand, september_solar_production, solar_efficiency_factor, 
                  new_peak_demand, september_peak_demand * peak_demand_rate, new_demand_charge, demand_savings]
}

comparison_df = pd.DataFrame(comparison_data)
comparison_df

# Define the peak hours
peak_hours_start = 14  # 2:00 PM
peak_hours_end = 18    # 6:00 PM

# Calculate solar production during peak hours for each month
df['Solar Production During Peak'] = df.apply(lambda row: max(0, row['Solar Production'] * (peak_hours_end - peak_hours_start)), axis=1)

# Define peak demand charge rate
peak_demand_rate = 5.49000  # $/kW

# Calculate peak demand reduction for each month
df['Peak Demand Reduction'] = df['Solar Production During Peak'] * peak_demand_rate

# Sum up the reductions for the entire year
total_peak_demand_reduction = df['Peak Demand Reduction'].sum()

# Display the DataFrame with the new columns
df[['Month', 'Solar Production During Peak', 'Peak Demand Reduction']]

# Calculate peak demand reduction for each month (Solar Production During Peak * Rate)
